unnormalised: In a bid to streamline healthcare access, the National Health Authority (NHA) has announced that starting 1st Oct, all hospitals empanelled under Ayushman Bharat – Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (AB-PMJAY) will be required to integrate their systems with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM). This move aims to create a unified digital healthcare ecosystem, improving efficiency and transparency.
normalised: In a bid to streamline healthcare access, the N-H-A has announced that starting first October, all hospitals empanelled under Ayushman Bharat – Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (A-B-P-M-J-A-Y) will be required to integrate their systems with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (A-B-D-M). This move aims to create a unified digital healthcare ecosystem, improving efficiency and transparency.

unnormalised: A key component of this integration involves the use of unique health IDs, known as ABHA numbers, for all patients. Think of it as your permanent health address! Each ABHA number, resembling something like 1234-5678-9012-3456, will store a patient's medical history, test results, and treatment records securely. No more lugging around thick files of medical reports, folks!
normalised: A key component of this integration involves the use of unique health I-D-s, known as A-B-H-A numbers, for all patients. Think of it as your permanent health address! Each A-B-H-A number, resembling something like one thousand two hundred and thirty four hyphen five thousand six hundred and seventy eight hyphen nine thousand and twelve hyphen three thousand four hundred and fifty six, will store a patient's medical history, test results, and treatment records securely. No more lugging around thick files of medical reports, folks!

unnormalised: "This is a game-changer for Indian healthcare," said Dr. R.S. Sharma, CEO of NHA, during a press conference held on 20/09/2024. "The ABDM will revolutionize how healthcare is delivered and accessed in our country."
normalised: "This is a game-changer for Indian healthcare," said Doctor R.S. Sharma, C-E-O of N-H-A, during a press conference held on twentieth September two thousand and twenty four. "The A-B-D-M will revolutionize how healthcare is delivered and accessed in our country."

unnormalised: The initiative aims to reduce paperwork, eliminate duplicate records, and facilitate seamless data sharing between healthcare providers. So, if you visit AIIMS Delhi and then go to a private clinic in Mumbai, your medical history will be readily available to both doctors, with your consent, of course. Pretty cool, right?
normalised: The initiative aims to reduce paperwork, eliminate duplicate records, and facilitate seamless data sharing between healthcare providers. So, if you visit A-I-I-M-S Delhi and then go to a private clinic in Mumbai, your medical history will be readily available to both doctors, with your consent, of course. Pretty cool, right?

unnormalised: But what about those without an ABHA number? Not to worry! Hospitals will be equipped to generate ABHA numbers on the spot. Just carry your Aadhaar card or any other valid ID, and they will get you sorted.
normalised: But what about those without an A-B-H-A number? Not to worry! Hospitals will be equipped to generate A-B-H-A numbers on the spot. Just carry your Aadhaar card or any other valid I-D, and they will get you sorted.

unnormalised: Industry experts are optimistic about the long-term benefits of ABDM. "It's a step in the right direction," commented Ms. Priya Iyer, a healthcare analyst, to a local news channel. "The integration of health IDs will not only improve patient care but also help in better policy planning and resource allocation."
normalised: Industry experts are optimistic about the long-term benefits of A-B-D-M. "It's a step in the right direction," commented Ms. Priya Iyer, a healthcare analyst, to a local news channel. "The integration of health I-D-s will not only improve patient care but also help in better policy planning and resource allocation."

unnormalised: However, concerns remain about data privacy and security. The NHA assures that all data will be encrypted and stored securely, with strict measures in place to prevent unauthorized access. And with all protocols in place, it looks to be an important step for the future of Indian healthcare.
normalised: However, concerns remain about data privacy and security. The N-H-A assures that all data will be encrypted and stored securely, with strict measures in place to prevent unauthorized access.
